Posts.Content: Sorry, forgot to mention the DRE. He stated that my prostate felt normal, as was actually small. No idea if that's even relevant to anything....other than maybe it was his way of saying that it wasn't enlarged?
Posts.Title: 45 yrs old, PSA=2.45...neep a pep talk

Posts.Title: 45 yrs old, PSA=2.45...neep a pep talk

Posts.Content: GP drew blood for my quarterly blood tests, adding a PSA test as I'd just turned 45. PSA came back at 2.25, so she sent me to a Urologist for a follow-up. Second test came back at 2.45, but not knowing any better, I had sex 18hrs prior to second test. (don't remember if I had sex prior to first test) DRE was normal. He would like to wait until January for a third test, which makes sense, but I will be the first to admit, I want immediate answers, and this just isn't cutting it. As for the Urologist, he's performed approx 150 Da Vinci procedures. We didn't get into specific success numbers, but is 150 enough practice? Or should I go looking for another Doc if it does turn out that I have cancer? And yes, if I do have cancer, I want it cut out. I don't care if I wear diapers every day...just as long as I can see my son turn into an adult.

Posts.Title: 45 yrs old, PSA=2.45...neep a pep talk

Posts.Content: Wondering why we seem to be getting a biopsy prior to a MRI (or no MRI at all). With 3T/4T MRIs, tumors can very easily be found, and they're non-invasive scans...no needles, and thus, no chance of infection. I'm still waiting for my follow-up same-day PSA test in February, but my Doc has only mentioned a biopsy, and never a MRI. I don't see any downsides outweighing any benefits. Yes, a biopsy is necessary to determine cancer type, but with so many biopsies missing the tumor (edit: very surprised regarding the percentage of false negatives), wouldn't a MRI prior to the procedure pretty much ensure the samples are taken from the correct location within the prostate? Am I missing something?
Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut ...MRI with rectal coil BEFORE the biopsy. The hospitals around here are specifically advertising their new 3T machines for prostate cancer (and breast cancer) detection. I just don't understand...if a non-invasive test can: 1) Determine if there's a tumor, or tumor-like growth, and 2) Locate the exact position of the tumor, making an effective biopsy a cinch; Then why not use it? Can my doc really need rent money that badly? (sarcasm)
Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut ...MRI with rectal coil BEFORE the biopsy. The hospitals around here are specifically advertising their new 3T machines for prostate cancer (and breast cancer) detection. I just don't understand...if a non-invasive test can: 1) Determine if there's a tumor, or tumor-like growth, and 2) Locate the exact position of the tumor, making an effective biopsy a cinch; Then why not use it? Can my doc really need rent money that badly? (sarcasm)
Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: I'm all for an ol' fashioned biopsy. I just don't get why a test, that could very well make the difference between a false negative and actually finding the cancer, PURPOSFULLY not be done. Regarding cost/insurance, I doubt that undergoing multiple biopsies (which several members of this forum have had) is cheaper than one MRI and one well-guided biopsy.
Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut ...MRI with rectal coil BEFORE the biopsy. The hospitals around here are specifically advertising their new 3T machines for prostate cancer (and breast cancer) detection. I just don't understand...if a non-invasive test can: 1) Determine if there's a tumor, or tumor-like growth, and 2) Locate the exact position of the tumor, making an effective biopsy a cinch; Then why not use it? Can my doc really need rent money that badly? (sarcasm)
Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut You must know and define your goals. The MRI with rectal coil cannot diagnose cancer for sure, but it can tell you that you "for sure" need a biopsy. . That's half my goal, right there...the other half is to give the doc a more precise target other than the entire prostate. Sticking 12 needles into something the size of a pea (if the MRi actually finds something) is preferable to 12 needles being stuck, somewhat haphazardly, into something the size of a large walnut (no pun intended). I really am all for biopsies, I just want better ones. OT...how does the Doc know when it's OK to remove the catheter?

Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Simply put, you don't seem to understand why doctors don't want to order repeat PSA testing sooner than you think would be good. All you get by testing too soon is another test result that isn't reliable. Why would getting the test sooner than what the Doctor ordered make it unreliable? My guess, waiting 3-4 months between tests simply allows time for a significant enough change to take place. Three tests in one year, or 10 tests in one year...you're still going to arrive at the same numbers by the end. A test result is nothing more than a data point, and really, what's so bad about having more test results than what's normally obtained. If kept in perspective (a 2% rise is not the same as a 90% rise), can you really have too much data? I'm still going to my appointment in February, and I'm still planning on coordinating any possible future care with my doctor, but this test will satisfy my curiosity, more quickly, whether or not, and to what extent, sex affected MY scores.
Posts.Title: Ordering your own PSA test

Posts.Content: This seems to getting a little out of hand. I simply want to see if sex within 24hrs of my last test, and maybe my first test (I don't remember) had any effect on my levels. And it would seem to me, that having the third test, after abstaining for five days, so soon after the original two tests, would provide a decent chance of determining that. Again, this test will not affect my future treatment in any way. And Bravehardon, no worries, he won't know...this test really is just for me. And Otago, me having a different view does not equate to not understanding the issue. Otherwise I could say the same thing to you.

Posts.Title: Ordering your own PSA test

Posts.Content: Just found out that I can order my own PSA test through my hospital's lab. ($30) I will not use the results to self-diagnose, but I fret, and waiting until the end of February for my next test is killing me. Not knowing any better, I had sex within 24hrs of both tests (they only mentioned bike riding), so I'll be taking the test on Friday to see if a week of abstinence will make a noticeable difference. EDIT: For anyone near a Sentara Lab, there's 20 tests from which to choose: http://sentara.3dcartstores.com/Sent...-Menu_c_1.html
